(Photo: Robert Deutsch-USA TODAY Sports) 
Jay-Z killed his ants with a sledgehammer back in 2001. "Takeover" was one of the most blistering moments in rap history, a brutally effective diss track that made overtly public his beefs with Nas and Prodigy from Mobb Deep. 
It also was a dope as hell track, with Kanye West (I miss the old Kanye) dropping an amazing Doors sample of "Five to One." Here's the song - with its many explicit and potentially offensive lyrics - in case y'all forgot. (How?!) 
Monday night, LeBron James made public his own war - with Charles Barkley. The words were as blunt and direct as any we've ever seen directed toward Barkley, the Hall of Famer-turned-TNT analyst who always drops the hottest takes. 
He then hopped on Twitter to make sure we understood . 
Quite simply, James - a huge Jay-Z fan - laid out his very own "Takeover." And we can prove it. Just look at these parallels: 
LeBron: "He's a hater. What makes what he says credible? Because he's on TV. I'm not going to let him disrespect my legacy like that." Jay-Z: "Hey, lil soldier, you ain't ready for war. R.O.C. too strong for y'all! It's like bringing a knife to a gunfight, pen to a test." 
You've got to set the tone early. You're not having it. You're bigger than this. But you're going to go there because they made you. 
LeBron: "I'm not the one who threw somebody through a window. I never spit on a kid. I never had unpaid debt in Las Vegas. I never said, 'I'm not a role model.' I never showed up to All-Star Weekend on Sunday because I was in Vegas all weekend partying." Jay-Z: "I got the pictures. I seen ya. Then you dropped 'Shook Ones,' switched your demeanor. Well, we don't believe you, you need more people." 
Barkley telling LeBron to act like a leader? Charles is ignoring his entire past. But James isn't, just like Hov didn't with Prodigy. 
LeBron: "All I've done for my entire career is represent the NBA the right way. Fourteen years, never got in trouble. Respected the game. Print that." Jay-Z: "You're not on my level, go get your brakes tweaked. I sold what your whole album sold in my first week. You guys don't want it with Hov." 
Never forget to explain how much better you are in a diss track. 
LeBron: "Go watch the '93 Finals when John Paxson hit the shot. Barkley and Jordan were laughing and joking with each other during one of the games while somebody's shooting a free throw. In the Finals. But, oh, nobody were friends back then." Jay-Z: "You said you've been in this 10. I've been in it five - smarten up, Nas. Four albums in 10 years? I could divide. That's one every - let's say, two. Two of them s- was due. One was 'nah,' the other was Illmatic. That's a one-hot-album-every-10-year average." 
Sure, James was throwing Barkley's own actions back in his face with this quote. Mostly, though, he was reminding Charles of his only shot at a ring and how he blew it. Barkley's 1993 was Nas' 1994. He never made it back to the Finals - a place James has been to over and over again, seven times. 
LeBron: "I know he wanted to retire a long time ago, but he can't. He's stuck up on that stage every week." Jay-Z: "Went from Nasty Nas to Esco's trash. Had a spark when you started, but now you're just garbage. Fell from top 10 to not mentioned at all." 
Pretty self-explanatory. Sometimes time writes its own endings for us. 
LeBron: "I went to see Melo at the Garden two years ago when we were in New York. They played Portland. I went up to a suite at halftime, and Phil Jackson didn't say one word to me. … I'm here to win ballgames and take care of my teammates and take care of my, what's that word, oh, my 'posse.'" Jay-Z: "So stop with that childish shit, n-, I'm grown. Please leave it alone, don't throw rocks at the throne. … Go play somewhere, I'm busy." 
Had to include the shots at Phil Jackson, which essentially were: Why are you even talking to me? 
LeBron: "And if this makes him want to talk to me, the schedule's out there. He knows every road arena I'll be in. Don't just come up to me at All-Star and shake my hand and smile." Jay-Z: "It's only so long fake thugs can pretend." 
The ultimatum. 
LeBron: "I'm tired of biting my tongue. There's a new sheriff in town." Jay-Z: "Gonna learn to respect the king. Don't be the next contestant on that Summer Jam screen." 
Make no bones about it. This was a threat. Skip Bayless and anyone else still trying to come at James better watch out. He'll undress you. 
The best part of this parallel is what came next in the Jay-Z vs. Nas beef. It's time for Barkley to come back over the top - with his own "Ether." What can he even say to equal the anguish of Nas' "What's sad is I love you 'cause you're my brother; you traded your soul for riches. My child, I've watched you grow up to be famous, and now I smile like a proud dad watching his only son that made it." 
We'll have to see if Barkley has the chops. For now, though, this was a takeover. Break's over. Read or Share this story: http://ftw.usatoday.com/2017/01/lebron-james-charles-barkley-rant-jay-z-takeover/ Most Popular
